title: HPV and Cervical Cancer: What's the Link?
author: Kathleen Doheny

content: Many things have been linked to cancer , from genetics to tobacco use. But we know for sure that most cervical cancer is caused by a sexually transmitted disease called human papilloma virus, or HPV.
That also means we can prevent most cases of cervical cancer. How? By preventing HPV through vaccinations and practicing safe sex .

content_blocks.text: Many things have been linked to cancer , from genetics to tobacco use. But we know for sure that most cervical cancer is caused by a sexually transmitted disease called human papilloma virus, or HPV.
That also means we can prevent most cases of cervical cancer. How? By preventing HPV through vaccinations and practicing safe sex .

sections.heading: What Is HPV?
content: HPV is the most common type of sexually transmitted disease, or STD . It's not one, but a group of more than 200 closely related viruses.
Sexually transmitted HPV comes in two different types:
HPV has been linked to cancers of the:
bullets: Low-risk HPV types cause genital warts on the penis or vagina .
High-risk HPV types cause cancers in both men and women.

Sexually transmitted HPV comes in two different types:
associated_bullets: Low-risk HPV types cause genital warts on the penis or vagina .
High-risk HPV types cause cancers in both men and women.

sections.heading: How Do You Get HPV?
content: You can catch HPV through oral, vaginal, and anal sex . The virus is so common that most men and women who are sexually active will have HPV at some point. You can pass HPV to your partner even if you don't know you're infected.
You can't catch HPV from a toilet set or swimming pool. It also doesn't pass from person to person through casual contact, like shaking hands.

content_blocks.text: You can catch HPV through oral, vaginal, and anal sex . The virus is so common that most men and women who are sexually active will have HPV at some point. You can pass HPV to your partner even if you don't know you're infected.
You can't catch HPV from a toilet set or swimming pool. It also doesn't pass from person to person through casual contact, like shaking hands.

sections.heading: How Does HPV Cause Cervical Cancer?
content: Most of the time HPV infections go away on their own in 1 to 2 years. Yet some people stay infected for many years.
If you don't treat an HPV infection, it can cause cells inside your cervix to turn into cancer. It can often take between 10 and 30 years from the time you’re infected until a tumor forms.

If you don't treat an HPV infection, it can cause cells inside your cervix to turn into cancer. It can often take between 10 and 30 years from the time you’re infected until a tumor forms.

sections.heading: Can You Prevent HPV?
content: One way to avoid HPV and cervical cancer is to get vaccinated. Two HPV vaccines are currently available:
Gardasil . This HPV vaccine is recommended for girls and boys between ages 9 and 14 in two doses, up to age 26. Three doses are recommended for those ages 15 and older.

Gardasil 9. This vaccine is for boys and girls and is routinely given at 11 or 12 through age 26, in two doses. It has been FDA-approved to be given to males and females from ages 27 to 45, with three doses recommended.
The key for all three vaccines is to get them before having sex for the first time -- and before being exposed to HPV. You need to get all three doses of the HPV vaccine for it to work.
Practicing safe sex is another way to avoid getting HPV. Use a latex condom every time you have sex. Condoms don't protect against HPV 100% of the time, but they can help.

The key for all three vaccines is to get them before having sex for the first time -- and before being exposed to HPV. You need to get all three doses of the HPV vaccine for it to work.
Practicing safe sex is another way to avoid getting HPV. Use a latex condom every time you have sex. Condoms don't protect against HPV 100% of the time, but they can help.

sections.heading: Does HPV Have Symptoms?
content: Often HPV causes no symptoms. Some types of HPV can cause genital warts. Warts are single bumps, or clusters of bumps that look sort of like cauliflower.
Genital warts can form around the:
HPV can also cause cervical cancer. Symptoms of cervical cancer include:
Cervical cancer often doesn't cause symptoms until it has already spread. That's why it's important to get screened with a Pap test.
bullets: Vagina, vulva, groin, anus, mouth, or throat in women
Penis, scrotum, thigh, groin, anus, mouth , or throat in men
Bleeding between periods or after menopause

sections.heading: Why Get a Pap Test?
content: A Pap test is one way to screen for cervical cancer. It can find this cancer early, when it's easiest to treat.

During a Pap test, the doctor takes a sample of cells from your cervix. That sample goes to a lab. It's tested to see if any of the cells have started to turn into cancer. Your doctor can also test the cells for HPV.

content_blocks.text: A Pap test is one way to screen for cervical cancer. It can find this cancer early, when it's easiest to treat.

During a Pap test, the doctor takes a sample of cells from your cervix. That sample goes to a lab. It's tested to see if any of the cells have started to turn into cancer. Your doctor can also test the cells for HPV.

content: Women should get screened:
Ask your doctor or gynecologist about your HPV and cervical cancer risks. Find out if you need to get vaccinated. And learn what other steps you can take to avoid cervical cancer.
bullets: With a Pap test once every 3 years - beginning at age 21, then at ages 24 and 27
With a Pap test and HPV test from age 30 and every five years thereafter up to age 65
Women can elect to continue Pap testing only every 3 years (without an HPV test)

content_blocks.text: Women should get screened:
associated_bullets: With a Pap test once every 3 years - beginning at age 21, then at ages 24 and 27
With a Pap test and HPV test from age 30 and every five years thereafter up to age 65
Women can elect to continue Pap testing only every 3 years (without an HPV test)

meta_description: How does HPV cause cervical cancer? And what can you do to protect yourself
